segments.text: The laboratories are smack right in the middle of the ship on the main deck and you get exactly the same kind of treatment.
If this were a commercial vessel that would be the engine room and the wells above the engine room and you'd be working in the bow or the stern.
And it's awfully nice when people come back from a cruise and say, what a wonderful vessel this is.
Well, the reason it's a wonderful vessel is it was built from scratch as an oceanographic vessel.
And a lot of care and experience went into placing the various units, placing priorities on space and things like that.
And when you begin to design a vessel that you go through and say, we have to have these X number of things.
We have to have trawls, for example.
We have to have nets.
And we put these here.
But if you have to... What you do is you get your scientists together, and it takes a period of maybe a year or maybe even longer, and you just thrash out one item at a time.
Everything is a compromise.
One fellow wants one thing, somebody else wants something else, and you eventually, through persuasion and argument, come up with a compromise in each unit.
When we got the Wacoma...
It was a stripped vessel.
It wasn't even completed.
And we spent about $850,000 outfitting it with the scientific equipment and gear.
And it took a lot of heartache to decide how to spend these resources because one person wants this and somebody else wants something different.
And every lab goes through the same sort of thing.
Now, do you check on its progress almost each day?
Do you stay beside it, or do you just?
No, the architect does this?
We have our own clerk of the works that usually does this.
We usually have an engineer that is right there all the time.
What about a ship's captain?
How do you decide and pick that?
Well, we don't have to very often because we still have the captain that...
One of our captains has been with us about 15 years now, and the other one's been since we got the first big ship.
He came aboard, we'd had it for about two months, and he's been with us, and this has been 12 or 13 years.
We do not have a very big overturn in our ship's officers, and they tend to stay.
Most of them live in Newport and have families, and almost all of our crews are ex-combatants.
service people rather than from the merchant marine.
And I think they tend to be a little more, well, they like a home life a little bit more than the merchant mariners do.
How often, how many days per year are you out to sea in your ship?
Am I personally?
No.
The ship is usually out in about 250 days, the big ship and about 175 for the little one.
It just got back from six months off South America.
It left on the 10th of January and got back on the 3rd of July.
And then I take it you take crews out and back.
That is, people will be on it about six weeks, be replaced by others, or will somebody spend six months on that vessel?
The crew spends six months.
We have a rule that we can't keep them longer than that without shipping them home for two weeks.
So we tend to take a long cruise every other year.
We work locally on cruises not more than two months long, maybe go to Hawaii or Alaska, but then every other year we plan a long cruise.
usually split up into four or five parts, and a different group goes and exchanges.
We had chemists part of the time, geologists, geophysicists, and physical people were our last group.
And does it seem to you, this is a fair question, does it seem to you there are less tensions between crews and ships and so forth now than there were when you first started?
Less tensions?
Less tension, yes.
Between being at sea longer, having crowded ships, or what?
Conditions were pretty primitive when I started out.
We started out in EWS Scripps, which is about 100 feet long.
Had a crew of about five people.
It was really kind of dangerous.
I'm surprised we didn't lose ourselves.
And then we moved up to the first of the Revell fleet, the old Baird and Horizon.
They really weren't very comfortable.
Diesel fumes all the time, and quarters were right up in the bow, and you were seasick most of the time.
And now our ships are much more comfortable.
How long did you stay on those first cruises?
As a rule, most ships, this is just a general number, can't stay at sea for more than about six weeks at the most.
And this is about the maximum that people put up with each other, too.
If they're out that long, then they're all at each other's throats, crew and size.
So the normal leg is about a month long, for us at any rate.
And I think this is true for most of the other labs.
They tend to work for a month and then come into a port.
OK.
And plan the cruise this way.
Right.
Get my 15 second delay here.
Now we were talking really about outfitting ships and time spent at sea.
And you had explained that the staff remained about the same all the time and that
that after a certain amount of time at sea, usually a month, that the tensions increased enough where you thought you had to come back to port.
Is this...
Excuse me.
Is there anything else you would like to add about vessels, outfitting vessels?
I don't think so, unless you have a specific question.
No, the next series of questions I have concern...
curriculum, really, when you arrived here and established your department.
Was there any particular weakness you thought that appeared in oceanography as a whole that you tried to aim your department towards?

Well, I've been a little bit insistent on one point, and that is that no matter what branch of oceanography a student goes in, he has to take the fundamental four basic courses in biology, chemistry, geology, and physical oceanography.
And that is not generally held in most places, but I feel that anybody that's working in the ocean, it ought to have at least knowledge of some of the literature and nomenclature in all fields.
And so beside this, you had no particular design or goal for the curriculum?
No, not in particular.
Of course, I came from Scripps, so I designed it pretty much after what I'd seen then.
Okay.
Scripps, like the University of Oregon, or like Oregon State, excuse me,
in our university seems to stress research probably more than some of the other institutions.
Do you suppose that's why that you stressed research more here, or was it more simply funding?
I think it was funding, primarily, that gave us the stress there.
But we have not neglected our educational side at all.
I think we have perhaps as many students as anyone.
We have about 120 students and put a lot of effort into it.
I just wanted to make sure we got that point down on tape.
Now, I only really have two or three more questions then, and this is a different kind of nature of things.
Perhaps again speculative questions if you would like.
Do you suppose that now that it seems as if oceanography and meteorology are more intertwined than ever before,
Do you suppose there will be more chances for oceanography to perhaps tie itself up in joint projects with NASA and these sorts of projects in terms of weather predicting?
Do you see more interest?
I don't really see.
I've never thought about this, but I don't see any real prospect.
There have only been a few teams where both are on it.
The meteorologists seem to be a little independent of the oceanographers.
That's perfect.
There have been several complaints, I know, among people working in the atmosphere and the ocean about the lack of cooperation between two groups.
Have you felt this has limited you in your career?
No.
Not any at all?
I don't think so, because I consider myself a meteorologist.
I'm a fellow of the American Meteorological Society.
I've been on their boards and committees, and I just work in both fields.
Okay.
But a person without this training might not feel free to do this.
Now, is there anything you'd like to add to the table?
What have I missed?
I think you've done a pretty thorough job.
I don't think I have any particular message for posterity.
No, you can think of nothing you'd like to say to future historians.
No, not in particular.
I think the primary ingredient of success in any field is just plain hard work, and I think that shows.
And that's just what you would attribute your success to?
I think so, yeah.
I couldn't disagree more than that.
